Timeouts
> > that are less than the maximum GC pause will always be unreliable.
Might
> > that be the cause of the instability you see?
>
>
> The problem here is not about GC pauses, it's simply that for(;;)
doesn't
> have any yield points, so you will never be able to interrupt it.

for (;;) *DOES* have yield points -- you need it for a correctly
functioning GC. However, java does not use these yield points by
default, it only uses one with sleep. To abort a for(;;) I think you
need thread.stop.

-- Ben
